snippet.title: Labor set to reject $3 billion casino
snippet.content:
THE State Government is set to torpedo a $3 billion casino resort earmarked for the Gold Coast's Southport Spit. Chinese-backed company ASF had planned a five-tower integrated resort, including a casino, on Crown land on the Spit. ASF had been named as the preferred proponent for the resort and a second Coast casino. But The Courier-Mail understands Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk and State Development Minister Anthony Lynham are set to announce the project's death knell at a press conference at noon today, where they are expected to announce a three-storey height limit for the area as well as a master plan. The project would have been a major job creator but was unpopular with many locals. Opposers, led by former Beattie government minister Judy Spence, had railed against the ASF proposal. Mayor Tom Tate's plans for a cruise ship terminal on the Spit are not expected to be impacted by the Government's decision. It comes a month after ASF Consortium director he was in talks with Caesars Entertainment regarding the proposal. "ASF Consortium has been in ongoing discussions with a number of world-class operators," he said in July.
